posts.cooked:
Hello! I’m currently working on slides for a lecture I’m giving about bumpers in a month. I want to add a section that addresses common issues teams have with bumpers and how to solve them. I’m sure that there are a bunch I just didn’t think about, forgot, or just never came across personally. So my question is: What Bumper issues has your team had or what bumper issues have you seen other teams have? If you also have a solution that’s great and post that as well but if you don’t that’s fine I just want to know. Thank you.

EDIT: I’d also like to ask “What do you think would be important to add in a presentation about bumpers?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: My bumper obsession is definitely healthy...

posts.custom_user_title: My bumper obsession is definitely healthy...

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
@SurfGear probably has a few horror stories.

Common issues I’ve seen include: -not following the Robot Perimeter -wood screws WILL tear out–not if, when -ditto for poorly-designed machine screws -fabric coming off, particularly if it’s just a cover over the normal bumpers

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: Eric got the major issues. I’ll add all dimensional measurements being off. Saw a team with 4" tall bumpers before. Incorrectly sized numbers painted on. Anything that requires meeting a measurement requirement in the second half of the game manual is doomed.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Some mostly aesthetic ones.

Not ironing on numbers straight (or otherwise number application is wonky)

Cutting fabric too small and not having enough to staple

Lack of care folding extra fabric around corners

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked:
I’ll go the other way and toss out something that turned out to work really well for us.  We used the 1/2" or 3/4" floor tile (EPDM) for our robot this year.

We cut it in bumper height strips and glued it to the backing (or previous layers as we build up to the required thickness) using spray adhesive (3m Type 77 maybe?).  We offset the layers in the corners each layer so they alternated overlapping making for a really solid and clean corner.  It avoided all of the problems with securing pool noodles and gave you a nice base to work around for the fabric.

Our bumpers were a pair of U-shaped assemblies so we left the padding extending past the short legs so you only had to worry about fitting things to the outside corner.  We trimmed them to length nice and square the next day when the adhesive was fully set.

You end up with a sort of Minecraft-y square bumper but they are solid and easy to wrap because you can kind of wrap the fabric like you were doing a birthday present and not worry about the radiuses and curvatures of the old pool noodle deal.

We build these super nice robots and then jank them all up with half-baked bumpers but these turned out really nice.

So there is a positive for your story as well…

posts.name: Christine Low
posts.cooked: Would love to see any pics of these. Got any from during their build/assembly?

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
The pain points in semi-recent memory:

2014: We did the reversible bumpers…except a kid painted the number on upside-down.  Fixed it with careful cutting and hotel sewing kits.  Now we don’t do reversibles.

2019: We used stock AM14U front mounts on the sides, and that put the wood too far out from the frame.  Didn’t notice it until Smoky Mountains inspectors decided to make us the example.  We were slightly undersized, so we added some brackets to the frame to alter the frame perimeter (as defined) instead of altering the bumpers.

2022: Hard defense at Championship had some wood screws pull out of the wood, which cost us an E-stop.  We prefer T-nuts through the wood now.

Virtually every year: We fight the AM14U bumper brackets a lot to get them to behave with their C-shaped vision for bumpers.  The last couple years, we’ve just punted and made four straight segments.  I don’t like it, but it passes.

2025: Ordered the AndyMark roll of bumper fabric like every other in recent memory, because it’s enough.  Except it wasn’t for the bulkier floor tile setup we were running this year, and we were finishing bumpers at FSC Hartsville.  Fortunately, the FSC Bumper Elves desk had extra material to save our butts (it’s why one of our blue bumpers is a funky shade).  I’m probably going to ping them ahead of time for 2026 to figure out what we need to order instead, as two rolls from AM is a little extravagant and begging for the leftovers to go missing.

As for people sticking together floor tile billets, allow me to cosign YYXLIFE carpet tape on the past recommendation of a user here.  It’s just the right amount of stickum that you can undo it in a problem.

We lay out the sizes we need using Opticutter ; five packs of Harbor Freight tiles should cover a robot well, but each side of a robot will be two chunks of foam.  Generally, we laminated 6-tile billets and cut to size; we would then shuffle around tiles to make 5-tile stacks of the appropriate size to actually run on the robot.  (Doing 6 at a time meant fewer cuts were needed.)  This is what it looked like for one set of robot foam, in this case 10591’s bumpers:

IMG_1187 1920×1440 297 KB

IMG_1187 1920×1440 297 KB

IMG_1187 1920×1440 297 KB

posts.name: Christine Low
posts.cooked: I will be giving a presentation about Bumpers at the Mentor Conference Aug 22-23.  Happy to share my presentation after the conference (assuming I FINISH it by then!)

posts.name: Christine Low
posts.cooked:
#1 source of problems with bumpers - not planning in advance/taking them seriously.

But to be fair - 2024 and earlier Bumper rules were detailed and “persnickety”.  Building bumps could be very tedious, un-rewarding work, and required a weird skill set that very few people have.

Many reasons for this, but I think it boiled down to “Woodie Flowers designed the original and if you don’t follow these instructions PERFECTLY the bumpers won’t protect your robot”.  If teams built a “delicate” robot, they would suffer and learn to test prototypes more thoroughly.  With bumpers - rarely were they tested, or even inspected after matches.  Until the 2024 game…

When the Bumper Working Group removed the “we are protecting you from yourselves” rules, teams now have the agency to design the bumps as part of the robot.  Build better bumpers and you can effectively protect your robot.    Cheap out, do a crummy last-minute bumper build - well, that’s on you now.

But to your question -   common problems I saw that were just hellacious to fix at an event

bumper numbers too small

bumper numbers wrapping corners

non-durable fabric (didn’t buy fabric in advance)

bumper mounts that ripped off/bent/broke and were OBVIOUSLY never tested or planned into the design

posts.name: CEF
posts.cooked: Convertible bumpers where The robot drove fine as red, But the velcro flap dragged on the ground as blue.

posts.name: Luis Mota
posts.cooked: Getting to load in and realizing the bumpers were shorter in height as permited, so need to use another team’s shop on the night to make brand new bumpers, but it was a fun night. Remember always to check every part of the manual even bumpers measures guys.

posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked:
Decide to add a layer of foam tiles around the pool noodles for extra padding and forget to realize that it adds distance…and use some use some old c shaped bumpers for testing so you don’t realize until you go to comp

image 546×580 66.1 KB image 195×282 2.73 KB (we took it off on the front+back but left it on the sides for extra protection)

image 546×580 66.1 KB

image 546×580 66.1 KB

image 195×282 2.73 KB

image 195×282 2.73 KB

The whole reason why I’ve been wanting to do a bumper presentation was because I’ve seen what happens when teams don’t take them seriously/underestimate the time it takes to make them/don’t plan them in advanced at competitions. I’m really happy someone agrees with that. I’ve helped teams make bumpers from almost scratch during practice days at competitions because of this and they were barely finished in time to be allowed to play the next day. I’ve mostly noticed it with teams that are newer to FRC and smaller teams.

posts.cooked: Also I forgot to mention in the original post that so far my slides consist of the 2025 rule changes, rule review, the different types of bumpers and the different parts that make up bumpers (fabric, frame, mounting, padding, numbers, bumper corners). A lot of the answers from this post were originally meant for a “bumper misconception and mistakes” section but it looks like I have a lot of tweaking to do for other parts so thank you everyone. I’d also like to add on a bit to the original question which is “what do you think would be important to add in a presentation about bumpers?”

posts.name: Katie Widen
posts.cooked:
Aligning the brackets that connect the bumper to the frame, especially with the kit frames

Or more broadly, mounting bumpers. Idk whenever I’m in charge it’s a struggle.

Keep in mind we’re talking about hand drill level of tooling.

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
Katie_UPS:

Keep in mind we’re talking about hand drill level of tooling.

If it makes you feel better, 1293’s 2023 bumpers were done on a CNC router, with a design mentor who worked at PTC and a professional machinist in on the process, and it was still a multi-hour process to get them beaten into place the first time.

And what’s worse, I don’t know where to point AndyMark’s engineers (who I hold in high regard) to make improvements.

posts.name: Andrew W
posts.cooked: We had issues and had to rebuild the robot inbetween our regionals, and also rebuild both robot’s bumpers. We spent hours taking them apart and putting them together due to issues with trying all sorts of fabrics and the mounts kept breaking. We had to fix them in the hotel on multiple nights at the event, and yet the iron on numbers still came off gradually until finals. What we should’ve done was test things on a smaller scale (ideally before the season) to help us get it right without all the pain, and really just having better planning for them overall. (Also avoid rebuilds)

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked: Let me see what I can find - we’re recovering one bumper so that will be a good time to grab some pics if I can’t find any.

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked:
SurfGear:

#1 source of problems with bumpers - not planning in advance/taking them seriously.

100% on that - all the focus goes towards the robot itself and then a freshman gets assigned to “make bumpers” - whatever that means…

You need to take them seriously enough to do them right - which to me means as seriously as the rest of the robot because if you show up with bad bumpers, the best that can happen is you get held off the field until you get them on and off again which for siome bumpers is way more of a nightmare than others (plus it’ just not great given how tight competition schedules are).

Worst case, you’re messing around with bumper reworking at the event and that takes a lot more of your time off the table - you see this every time.  Not only do you waste time, you generate the impression that you showed and weren’t fully ready to compete and I don’t like making that impression.
